events.name: Asbestos strke
events.description: Bitter strike at Asbestos, pitting the labour movement, intellectuals and large parts of the Roman Catholic clergy against the America-owned Johns-Manville Company and the provincial government of Maurice Duplessis.

events.name: Mining industry established
events.description: Establishment with substantial help from the provincial government of a huge iron mine at Schefferville in northern Quebec by a consortium of American steel companies and a copper mine at Muurdochville in the Gaspé by Toronto-based Noranda Mines Ltd.

events.name: Murdochville strike
events.description: Six-month strike at Murdochville that tore Quebec apart as Asbestos had eight years earlier.

events.name: Duplessis dies
events.description: Death of Duplessis at Schefferville after a fifteen-year reign as premier, opening the way for the defeat of his Union Nationale party.

events.name: Liberals elected
events.description: Election of Liberals under Jean Lesage and beginning of the Quiet Revolution.

events.name: Jean Drapeau elected
events.description: Election of Jean Drapeau as mayor of Montreal with promises to clean up the city.

events.name: Separatism stirs
events.description: Formation of the first separatist groups, including the Rassemblement pour l'Indépendence Nationale.

events.name: Liberals gain increased majority
events.description: Re-election of the Liberals with an increased majority, on a platform of nationalization of Quebec's hydroelectric power companies (pushed by Natural Resources minister René Lévesque) and a slogan of Maîtres Chez Nous - Masters in our Own House.

events.name: Nationalist Demonstrations
events.description: First large nationalist demonstrations of the sixties; protest outside Canadian National Railways headquarters in Montreal against the CNR's lack of a French-Canadian vice-president.

events.name: FLQ appears
events.description: Appearance of the first Front de Liberation Québécois (FLQ); bombings of federal buildings and mailboxes in English-speaking Westmountl death of one person and maiming of another; capture and imprisonment and beginning of the Lesage government's wide-ranging persecution of FLQ.

events.name: Quebec Ministry of Education created
events.description: Formation of Quebec's first department of education.

events.name: Educational Reforms
events.description: Lesage government's wide-ranging educational reforms.

events.name: Le samedi de la matraque
events.description: "Le samedi de la matraque" - Crushing of the demonstration against Queen Elizabeth's visit to Quebec City.

events.name: Marchand resigns
events.description: Resignation of Jean Marchand as president of the Confederation of National Trade Unions and his replacement by Marcel Pepin.

events.name: Anti-Duplessis leaders reborn as elected Liberals
events.description: Election to federal House of Commons as Liberals of the "three wise men" - Jean Marchand, Pierre Elliott Trudeau, Gérard Pelletier - who had been leaders of the anit-Duplessis movement.

events.name: Union Nationale elected
events.description: Defeat of the Lesage Liberals and return of the Union Nationale under Daniel Johnson; nine percent of the vote for RIN.

events.name: FLQ activities
events.description: Second FLQ under ideological leadership of Pierre Vallières and Charles Gagnon; bombings of strikebound plants and two deaths; arrest of Vallières and Gagnon in New York City.

events.name: Strike crushed
events.description: Strike by Quebec's Romain Catholic teachers crushed by the provincial government.

events.name: Vive le Québec libre
events.description: Visit of President Charles de Gaulle to Quebec and his "Vive le Québec libre!" speech from the balcony of Montreal's City Hall.

events.name: Levesque leaves Liberals
events.description: Departure of Réne Lévesque from the Liberal Party and formation of the Mouvement Souveraineté-Association.

events.name: MIS elected
events.description: Election of members of the uninilinguist Mouvement pour l'Intégration Scolaire to the school board in the Montreal suburb of St-Léonard.

events.name: RIN Demonstrates; Liberals are elected
events.description: Large bottle-theowing RIN demonstration in Montreal against St-Jean-Baptiste Day parade appearance of Prime Minister Trudeau, helping to produce Trudeau's large electoral majority the next day.

events.name: Bertrand to Premier
events.description: Sudden death of Premier Johnson and accession to the premiership of Jean-Jacques Bertrand.

events.name: FLQ reappears
events.description: Reappearance of the FLQ; bombings of Montreal stock exchange, Noranda Mines office, and other corporate centres.

events.name: CEGEP student revolt
events.description: Massive revolt of CEGEP students, occupation of school buildings all over the province, and 10,00-strong demonstration in Montreal.

events.name: Parti Québécois formed
events.description: Unification of MSA (Mouvement souveraineté-association) and the right-wing Ralliement National to form the Parti Québécois; absorption of most of the RIN into the PQ.

events.name: MLT at airport
events.description: Mouvement de Libération du Taxi (MLT) demonstration at Montreal Airport, with buses overturned and Molotov cocktails thrown,

events.name: McGill Demo
events.description: Large demonstration in front of the gates of McGill University in Montreal, demanding its conversion into a French-language university.

events.name: Union Nationale confirms Bertrand amid demonstration
events.description: Union Nationale conference confirming Bertrand in the premiership; large demonstration outside.

events.name: St-Léonard demonstrations
events.description: Demonstration in St-Léonard in support of unilingual schools, ending in the reading of the riot act and charging of three people with sedition.

events.name: October Seventh
events.description: One day strike by Montreal police; MLT demonstration in front of Murray Hill garage; exchange of sniper fire with one person killed; looting and window-breaking in downtown shopping area; calling of federal troops into Montreal

events.name: Bill 63 demonstrations
events.description: Huge demonstrations in Montreal and Quebec City against Bill 63, a government measure confirming English as an official language of education.

events.name: FLQ release demonstration
events.description: Demonstration in Montreal demanding the release of Vallières and Gagnon, including window-breaking in the St. James Street financial district, leading to Drapeau's anti-demonstration bylaw.

events.name: Lapalme contract expires
events.description: Expiry of contract of Montreal mail-truck drivers - "les gars de Lapalme" - and refusal of federal government to rehire them, setting the stage for a long conflict.

events.name: 1970 election places Liberals on top, PQ second
events.description: Election of a Liberal government under Robert Bourassa with 72 of the 108 National Assembly seats and 45 per cent of the popular vote after a campaign whose main feature was the surprising strength of the PQ; the PQ was second in the popular vote with 24 per cent but captured only seven seats.

events.name: Vallières and Gagnon released by Liberals
events.description: Release of Vallières and Gagnon by new Liberal Justice Minister Jérôme Choquette.

events.name: October Crises begins
events.description: Kidnapping of British trade commissioner James Cross by Libération cell of the FLQ and beginning of the October crisis.

events.name: FLQ Manifesto read on Radio-Canada
events.description: Reading of the FLQ manifesto on Radio-Canada in response to the kidnappers' demand.

events.name: Laporte Kidnapped
events.description: Television statement by Choquette refusing the FLQ's demands; kidnapping of Quebec Labour Minister Pierre Laporte by the Chenier cell of the FLQ.

events.name: Moderates favour FLQ
events.description: Statement by a group of French Canadian moderates calling on the government to meet the FLQ's demands in order to save Cross and Laporte.

events.name: Troops enter Montreal
events.description: Entry of federal troops into Montreal; mass rally at the Paul Sauvé arena in support of the aims of the FLQ.

events.name: Trudeau invokes War Measures Act
events.description: Invocation of the War Measures Act by the federal government; beginning of mass arrests

events.name: Laporte found dead
events.description: Discover of Laporte's body in the trunk of a car.

events.name: Drapeau re-elected, FRAP smeared
events.description: Re-election of Jean Drapeau with a clean sweep of Montreal city council seats in a climate of fear and smearing of the main opposition party, FRAP, as a front for the FLQ.

people.name: Archambault, Germain
people.description: Until his death in 1969, Montreal's chief taxi militant and strategist. Founder of the Mouvement de Libération du taxi (MLT).

people.name: Bertrand, Jean-Jacques
people.description: Union Nationale premier of Quebec, 1968-1970. Before that justice and education minister in the cabinet of Daniel Johnson.

people.name: Bourassa, Robert
people.description: Economist, Liberal member of the National Assembly and after May 1970 premier of Quebec. Related by marriage to the powerful Simard shipbuilding family.

people.name: Bourgault, Pierre
people.description: Longtime head of the Rassemblement pour L'Indépendance Nationale (RIN), Quebec's first major separatist party. After 1968 a leading member of the Parti Québécois.

people.name: Castonguay, Claude
people.description: Author of the massive Castonguay report on social welfare in Quebec and after May 1970 minister of social affairs in the cabinet of Robert Bourassa. A leader of the liberal wing of the cabinet.

people.name: Charbonneau, Yvon
people.description: After 1970, president of the Quebec Teachers Coropration and one of the leaders of the Common Front of labour.

people.name: Chartrand, Michel
people.description: Wartime activist in the Bloc Populaire, militant at the Asbestos strike in 1949 and the Murdochville strike in 1957, leading member of the Parti Socialiste du Québec (PSQ) in the early sixties, and after 1968 president of the Montreal Central Council of the Confederation of National Trade Unions (CNTU) and leader of the left wing of the Quebec labour movement.

people.name: Choquette, Jérôme
people.description: After May 1970, justice minister in the cabinet of Robert Bourassa and the cabinet's leading hardliner.

people.name: Cournoyer, Jean
people.description: Union Nationale labour minister, 1969-1970, and after the assassination of Pierre Laporte, in October 1970, Liberal labour minister. A member of the liberal wing of the cabinet.

people.name: Desmarais, Paul
people.description: After 1968, president of Power Corporation, the conglomerate with vast media, transport and other holdings in Quebec.

people.name: Diterlizzi, Frank
people.description: Italian-born leader of "les gars de Lapalme," the out-of-work mail-truck drivers whose struggle became a symbol in Quebec after 1970.

people.name: Drapeau, Jean
people.description: Unsuccessful anti-conscription candidate for the House of Commons in Outremont, 1942, anti-corruption crusader in Montreal in the early fifties, and mayor of Montreal from 1954 to 1957 and again after 1960.

people.name: Duplessis, Maurice
people.description: Union Nationale premier of Quebec, 1936-1939 and 1944-1959. Nicknamed "le Chef" and known for his corrupt and dictatorial methods of government.

people.name: Ferretti, Andrée
people.description: A leader of the Mouvement de Libération Populair (MLP), 1964-1965, the left wing of the Rassemblement pour l'Indépendance Nationale (RIN), 1965-1967, and the Front de Libération Populaire (FLP), 1968-1969. Now works for the Confederation of National Trade Unions (CNTU).

people.name: Gagnon, Charles
people.description: Along with Pierre Vallières, an idealogical leader of the 1966 Front de Libération du Québec (FLQ), which was responsible for several bombings of strike-bound factories. Spent 1966 to 1970 in jail as a result of his FLQ activities; released early in 1970, arrested again under the War Measures Act in October and finally acquitted of all charges. Broke with the FLQ in September 1971

people.name: Johnson, Daniel
people.description: Union Nationale cabinet minister, 1958-1960, leader of the Union Nationale, 1966-1968. Author of *Equality or Independence.* Died in office September 1968.

people.name: Kierans, Eric
people.description: President of the Montreal Stock Exchange, 1960-1963, minister of revenue and later minister of health in the cabinet of Jean Lesage, 1963-1966, president of the Quebec Liberal Party and the man responsible for forcing Réné Lévesque's resignation from the party, 1967, candidate for the federal Liberal leadership, 1968, and federal cabinet minister, 1968-1971.

people.name: Laberge, Louis
people.description: After 1964, president of the Quebec Federation of Labour; a "moderate" in the sixties but in the early seventies a leader of the Common Front and of the new militancy in Quebec labour.

people.name: Laporte, Pierre
people.description: Crusading journalist for *Le Devoir* in the late fifties, author of *The True Face of Duplessis*, minister of municipal affairs and cultural affairs in the cabinet of Jean Lesage, 1961-1966, candidate for the Quebec Liberal leadership, 1970, labour minister in the cabinet of Robert Bourassa, May-October 1970, killed by the Front du Libération du Québec (FLQ), October 1970.

people.name: Lemieux, Raymond
people.description: Leader of the Mouvement pour l'Intégration Scolaire (MIS; later the LIS - Ligue pour l'Intégration Scolaire), a group demanding that French be the language of all schools in Quebec.

people.name: Lemieux, Robert
people.description: Radical lawyer, defended many members of the Front de Libération du Québec (FLQ), including Pierre Vallières and Charles Gagnon; spokesman for the span type='link' key='flq'>FLQ during the October 1970 Crises.

people.name: Lesage, Jean
people.description: Federal minister of northern development and natural resources in the cabinet of Louis St-Laurent in the fities; provincial Liberal leader, 1958-1969, and premier of Quebec, 1960-1966. Presided over the Quiet Revolution.

people.name: Lévesque, Réné
people.description: Radical journalist and broadcaster in the fifties; a leader of the Radio-Canada producers' strike, 1959; minister in the cabinet of Jean Lesage and leader of the left wing of the cabinet, 1960-1966; responsible for the nationalization of Quebec hydroelectricity power companies, 1962; resigned from the Liberal party in 1967 and formed the separatist Mouvement Souveraineté-Association (MSA), after 1968 the Parti Québécois (PQ). Author of *An Option for Quebec*, 1968.

people.name: Marchand, Jean
people.description: Head of the Canadian Catholic Confederation of Labour (CCCL) and its successor, the Confederation of National Trade Unions (CNTU), until 1965. Along with Pierre Elliott Trudeau and Gérard Pelletier, one of the "three wise men" elected as Liberal members of the federal House of Commons in 1965. Federal minister of manpower and immigration, 1965-1968, and of regional economic expansion, after 1968. "Quebec lieutenant" to prime ministers Pearson and Trudeau.

people.name: Pelletier, Gérard
people.description: In the fifties, radical journalist and trade union activist and along with Pierre Elliott Trudeau a leading member of the left-liberal *Cité Libre* group. Editor-in-chief of *La Presse* in the early sixties. Along with Trudeau and Jean Marchand, one of the "three wise men" elected as Liberal members of the federal House of Commons in 1965. Federal secretary of state ater 1968. Author of *The October Crises*, 1970.

people.name: Pepin, Marcel
people.description: President of the Confederation of National Trade Unions (CNTU) after 1965, and in the early seventies one of the leaders of the Common Front of labour.

people.name: Ryan, Claude
people.description: Editor of *Le Devoir* after 1964 and a leading Catholic nationalist. Accused of being a member of the spurious "provisional government" plot, 1970.

people.name: Trudeau, Pierre Elliott
people.description: In the fifties, radical journalist and political theorist and later professor of law at the University of Montreal. Along with Gérard Pelletier, a leading member of the left-liberal *Cité Libre* group. Along with Pelletier and Jean Marchand, one of the "three wise men" elected as Liberal members of the House of Commons in 1965. Federal minister of justice, 1967-1968, and prime minister after 1968. Invoked the War Measures Act, 1970. Editor of and author of the chief essay in *The Asbestos Strike*, 1956; author of *Federalism and the French Canadians*, 1968.

people.name: Vallières, Pierre
people.description: Successor to Pierre Elliott Trudeau as editor of *Cité Libre*, 1963; forced out, 1964. Along with Front de Libération du Québec (FLQ), which was responsible for several bombings of strike-bound factories. Spent 1966 to 1970 in jail as a result of his FLQ activies; released early in 1970, arrested again under the War Measures Act in October and released again in 1971. Broke with the FLQ in December of 1971 and joined the Parti Québécois (PQ). Author of *White Niggers of America*, 1967, and *Choose!*, 1971.

people.name: Wagner, Claude
people.description: Law-and-order judge in the early sixties; justice minister in the cabinet of Jean Lesage, 1964-1966; unsuccessful candidate for the Quebec Liberal leadership, 1970; reappointed a judge, 1970; mentioned prominently as possible leader of Union Nationale and Crédiste parties, 1970-1971; leader of the Quebec wing of federal Progressive Conservative Party, 1972.

organizations.name: CEQ
organizations.description: Corporation des Enseignants du Québec (Quebec Teachers Corporation), the union of 70,000 teachers employed in Quebec's French Catholic school system. One of the components of the Common Front.

organizations.name: CCCL
organizations.description: See CNTU.

organizations.name: CAP (Comité d'Action Politique)
organizations.description: Comité d'Action Politique. One of a number of citizens' committees in various Montreal neighbourhoods organizing around local issues.The CAPs are grouped in the Front d'Action Politique (FRAP), the main opposition party to Mayor Jean Drapeau. (June's note - Good example of proletarians going past trade union conciousness (fuck Lenin))

organizations.name: Bloc Populaire Canadien
organizations.description: Organization formed during World War II around the conscription issue and the leading voice of French Canadian nationalism at the time. Dissolved after the war.

organizations.name: CFIA
organizations.description: Canadian Federation of Independent Associations, a federation of company unions often used by employers to keep real unions out.

organizations.name: Cité Libre
organizations.description: Left-liberal journal of the 1950s and early 1960s around which were grouped some of the major figures in the coalition opposing premier Maurice Deuplessis, including Pierre Elliott Trudeau and Gérard Pelletier.

organizations.name: CNTU
organizations.description: Confederation of National Trade Unions. Before 1961, the Canadian Catholic Confederation of . One of Quebec's major trade-union centrals, originally founded as a Catholic alternative to the "dangerous social tendencies" of American-supported unions, but later the main centre of radicalism in the Quebec labour movement. One of the components of the Common Front. (June's note: Good example of some dialectics + why we don't burn support with mass orgs)

organizations.name: Centrales des Syndicats Démocratiques
organizations.description: Centrales des Syndicats Démocratiques (Central of Democratic Trade Unions). Quebec trade-union central formed in 1972 after a split in the Confederation of National Trade Unions , by the right wing of the CNTU executive.

organizations.name: FLQ
organizations.description: At various times Front de Libération du Québec or Front de Libération Québécois. One of a series of organizations, from 1963 to 1971, pursuing an independent Quebec through terrorism. Responsible for the major political bombings and kidnappings.

organizations.name: FRAP
organizations.description: Front d'Action Politique. Montreal municipal political party opposing Mayor Jean Drapeau. Composed of a number of Comités d'Action Politique (CAPs).

organizations.name: Hydro-Québec
organizations.description: Quebec government hydroelectric power company, vastly expanded after 1962 with the nationalization of the province's private hydro companies. Became a symbol of the Quiet Revolution and Quebec public enterprise in the sixties.

organizations.name: Iron Ore Company of Canada
organizations.description: Company formed by a consortium of American steel companies in the 1950s to exploit Quebec iron ore. Opened an iron mine at Schefferville in northern Quebec after generous concessions from Premier Maurice Duplessis.

organizations.name: Ligue pour l'Intégration Scolaire
organizations.description: LIS. Before March 1969, Mouvement pour l'Intégration Scolaire (MIS). In the late sixties, a group demanding that French be the only language of instruction in Quebec schools. Originally formed to contest school-board elections in the Montreal suburb of St-Léonard.

organizations.name: Mouvement pour l'Intégration Scolaire
organizations.description: See Ligue pour l'Intégration Scolaire.

organizations.name: Mouvement de Libération du Taxi
organizations.description: MLT. Organization formed in 1968 to fight for the Interests of Montreal taxi drivers.

organizations.name: Parti Pris
organizations.description: Radical nationalist journal of the mid-sixties and a major intellectual influence on the development of the Quebec movement. Still survives as a publishing house.

organizations.name: PQ
organizations.description: Parti Québécois. Quebec political party, formed in 1968 by René Lévesque and advocating the political independence of Quebec, obtained through electoral means. Received 24 per cent of the vote in 1970 election.

organizations.name: QFL
organizations.description: Quebec Federation of Labour. One of Quebec's major trade-union centrals, consisting of the Quebec locals of unions afffiliated with the Canadian Labour Congress (CLC), and often with the AFL-CIO in the United States. Before 1971, rival of the Confederation of National Trade Unions, tending to be more conservative than the CNTU. Later, component of the Common Front with the CNTU and the Quebec Teachers Corporation.

organizations.name: RIN
organizations.description: Rassemblement pour l'Indépendance Nationale. Quebec s first large separatist party, formed in 1960. Received nine per cent of the vote in the 1966 election. Dissolved in 1968, with most of its members joining the Parti Québécois (PQ).

organizations.name: St-Jean-Baptiste Society
organizations.description: Catholic-nationalist patriotic organization, named after the patron saint of Quebec.

organizations.name: Union Nationale
organizations.description: After 1971, Unité-Québec. Conservative Quebec political party, in power 1936-1939, 1944-1960 and 1966-1970.

organizations.name: Unité Québec
organizations.description: See Union Nationale.
